Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from my younger brother: “Come quick! They’re about to announce the winners!” He’s been working for months on his science project, and today is the awards ceremony at his school. I promised I’d be there, cheering him on, just like he did for me last year. As I grab my keys, I catch a news alert—today is the last day to vote on a ballot measure that will decide whether our block gets a new park or a parking lot. The polling place is only a few blocks away, but it closes in two hours, and I haven’t voted yet. I know how important it is to participate, to have my voice heard as a citizen. But my brother is counting on me, and I can’t bear the thought of him scanning the crowd and not seeing me. My heart pounds as I stand in the hallway, torn between the expectations of being a supportive sister and a responsible citizen, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
